Body:
BC-SMITH-COLUMN-TEX 
CLINTON'S DIRECTION ON MENTAL ILLNESS IS THE RIGHT ONE

 (For use by NYTimes News Service clients) 
By JACK Z. SMITH 
c.1999 Fort Worth Star-Telegram 

   While growing up in a small town in Northeast Texas, I had one
persistent fear: that my mother would do something outrageous to
embarrass me.

   This fear was justified with devastating regularity.

   There was the time, for example, that I was playing touch
football with friends in my front yard. A stranger from out of town
stopped to ask for directions. For no apparent reason, my mother
stormed out of the house and cussed a blue streak at the man. I
stood there, red-faced and petrified, as my friends watched with
mouths agape.

   Some of my most terrifying moments came when my mother was
driving our Plymouth sedan and suddenly went into her A.J. Foyt
mode. When angered by something, and that was often, she could
instantly transform a 30 mph residential street into an 80 mph
autobahn.

   When in such a rage, she might pull up beside another car at a
stoplight, glare at its occupants and repeatedly honk her horn in a
menacing fashion. Some cowed individuals literally ran a red light
to escape her. I would bow my head in shame, waiting for my
mother's inexplicable fit to subside. Her local nickname was
``Runnin' Mary.''

   At home, my mother spent much of her time sitting, staring
detachedly into space and slowly puffing a cigarette. She often
complained incoherently that our home was plagued by people trying
to ``line in'' controlling thoughts through telephone wires.

   My mother, Mary Elizabeth Swint Smith _ whose initials
ironically spelled ``M.E.S.S.'' _ was classified by the doctors as
``paranoid schizophrenic.''

   I can remember, with great sadness, visiting her in the stark
setting of a state mental hospital when I was in the fifth grade.
Years later, tears would stream down my cheeks as I watched movies
such as ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' or ``A Woman Under the
Influence,'' films that vividly depicted the tragedy of mental
illness.

   So it was with no small pleasure that I read this past week how
President Clinton and Tipper Gore hosted a White House conference
at which they outlined various initiatives to help the mentally
ill.

   Clinton notified the 285 health plans used by federal employees
that they must provide the same degree of insurance coverage for
mental illness and substance abuse as for other health problems. He
urged other employers to provide similar coverage.

   Many insurance plans provide more limited coverage for mental
illnesses than other health problems. And many people lack health
insurance or are reluctant to seek professional help because of the
stigma associated with mental illness. That helps explain why many
mentally ill people populate our homeless shelters and jails.

   There are staggering public misperceptions about mental illness.
These illnesses are not caused by weaknesses in personality or an
inadequate upbringing, as some believe. Mental illnesses such as
schizophrenia and severe depression are caused by defects in the
way chemicals transmit messages within the brain.

   Most mentally ill people can benefit greatly from medication and
psychotherapy. Many, provided with such help, hold jobs and lead
near-normal lives.

   Dr. Peggy Bailey, a psychologist and board president of the
Mental Health Association of Tarrant County, Texas, says more
understanding is needed to foster public support for the mentally
ill.

   ``Our response to a woman who has been diagnosed with breast
cancer is profound and comforting and deeply sympathetic,'' she
said. ``We don't find, for the mentally ill or for their families,
that type of response when there is a diagnosis of mental illness.
I think that would make a huge difference.''

   Bailey said Clinton's call for more parity in insurance coverage
for mental illness is ``wonderful.'' Access to good medical care is
``critical,'' she said.

   Mental illness can destroy families. My mother's schizophrenia
contributed mightily to my parents' divorce when I was in junior
high. It crushed me when my dad remarried and moved to another
town. My mother was unemployable. My two brothers and I suffered
jolting financial and emotional hardships in my high school years.

   For most of my mother's adult life, she refused to take
medication that would have helped her (like many schizophrenics,
she was convinced that nothing was wrong with her). For 17 years, I
was her legal guardian, coping with some incredibly trying
situations as she continued declining mentally and physically.

   In the twilight of her life, we finally coaxed her into moving
150 miles from our hometown, Mount Pleasant, to an excellent
nursing home in Fort Worth.

   She began taking medication, ate better and regularly visited
me, my wife and our two daughters. I recall her happily tapping her
feet to Frank Sinatra tapes I bought her and chatting with my
daughters, whom she came to greatly love. In that period before her
death in 1993, her true nature _ that of a gentle and incredibly
kind human being _ revealed itself as never before.

   In her early years, my mother was an attractive and bright young
woman, a Baylor University graduate who enjoyed good books and
loved the Big Band music of her generation. Then the curse of
schizophrenia struck in her late 20s. She would never be the same.

   If family members and others had better understood her
condition, and if she had received better medical care, she could
have coped far, far better with the illness. Her life didn't have
to be the tragedy that it became.

   That's just as true today for the millions of Americans who
suffer from mental illness, many of whom are not receiving the full
help and understanding that they so desperately need.

   (Jack Z. Smith is a Star-Telegram editorial writer and
columnist. He can be reached at (817) 390-7724 or
jzsmith(at)star-telegram.com. Visit the Star-Telegram's online
services on the World Wide Web: www.star-telegram.com)
